admreg: Europe and Central Asia,Europe and Central Asia

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows: Outcome
            is unsatisfactory, sustainability is likely, institutional
            development impact is modest, and the performances of both
            the Bank and the Borrower are unsatisfactory. The main
            lessons concern the leverage that a credit instrument
            financed by IDA (International Development Association) can
            reasonably exert on Government policy making in the sector.
            The investment credit instrument by itself does not provide
            sufficient influence on Government to take the most
            difficult restructuring and pricing policy decisions.
            Conditionalities attached to the IDA adjustment credit, in
            the Second Structural Adjustment Credit Project (SAC II),
            were effective in getting the Government to tackle some of
            the most difficult sector issues, such as that of nonpayment
            in the gas sector. Another important observation is that
            supervision of an investment Credit provides a very
            effective way of gaining intimate knowledge of sector issues
            and this knowledge translates into sound advice to IDA on
            conditions for adjustment Credits.
